webTitle: Ireland austerity budget announced as markets cling to debt ceiling deal hopes - as it happened

fields.bodyText: PS: one last line from Dublin, from Henry McDonald: There was some pre-Hallowe'en ghoulish reaction to one aspect of the budget cuts from Fianna Fail, the main opposition party in Ireland. The party's finance spokesman Michael McGrath warned that "even the dead aren't safe from this Government." McGrath was referring to the measure in the budget which removes the €850 burial grant for some pensioners. Amid the confusion in Washington, European stock markets ended higher. Traders still think there's going to be a deal - despite the disfunctionality in Congress. The FTSE 100 finished 41 points higher at 6,549, up 0.64%, led by mining giant Rio Tinto (with Burberry bringing up the rear, down 7.6% following CEO Angela Ahrendts' exit to join Apple). Elsewhere on the stock market, Royal Mail shares finished 14p higher at 489p, a 48% jump on the float price. The German Dax closed at a new record high, up 0.9%, while the French CAC closed at its highest level since 2008. And that's a good time to stop. Live coverage of the Irish budget starts here There's analysis of Michael Noonan's statement here (from Henry)...and an explanation of how pensioners and the young unemployed will be hit hard. There's a list of key points here. Stay tuned to our US liveblog for developments in Washington. Could there be a deal by morning?..... We'll find out by tomorrow. Until then, thanks, and goodnight. GW Twists and turns in Washington this afternoon, with House Republicans proposing their own solution to the debt ceiling/budget deadlock, only to see it slapped down as a "partisan attempt to appease" the Tea Party by the White House. In the last few minutes, Senate majority leaders Harry Reid just declared that the House's proposal won't get through the Senate. Clearly a deal isn't agreed -- we'll be tracking it all through the day (and night?) here: House Republicans challenge bipartisan Senate deal to avert default – live Henry also points out that finance minister Michael Noonan hasn't bowed to pressure from Germany over Ireland's corporation tax rate: In defiance of criticism from the German SPD, Noonan told the Dail there would be no change in Ireland's relatively low corporation tax rate. "The tax rate is settled policy. We are 100% committed to the 12.5% corporation tax rate. This will not change," he said. The SPD in coalition talks with Angela Merkel has demanded the next German government led by her must ask the EU to review the Republic's corporation tax rate. The Social Democrats have argued that the low rate puts Ireland at an advantage over other EU states in terms of attracting foreign direct investment. There was one significant change, though. As I flagged up at 2.55pm, Noonan did promise to stop companies registered in Ireland from being 'stateless' for tax purposes. Dublin correspondent Henry McDonald flags up that this year's budget is a blow to Irish pensioners: One in ten of all pensioners over 70 will lose their full medical card entitling them to free health care. A subsidy of €114 per year to pay pensioners' telephone bills will also be scrapped while a death grant to pay for funerals - worth €850 - will be abolished. The move on pensioners could be a major political gamble given that they are one sector of the population guaranteed to get out and vote in elections. The Finance Minister also risked alienating pensioners, who make up a large proportion of savers, over his decision to increase tax on interest gained from savings - the so called DIRT tax rate – which is to be raised to 41%. Those unemployed under the age of 25 would also bear the brunt of the cuts with jobseeker's allowance being slashed from the current €144 per week to €100. The age of eligibility for the full social payment of €188 (still one of the most generous in the whole of the EU) will be raised to the age of 26. Some reaction to the changes in Irish budget from Twitter: On RTE, Brendan Keenan of the Irish Independent explained that increasing the duty on beer (10c), cigarettes (10c) and wine (50c); and the €150m/year bank levy, will provide a decent chunk of the revenue increases for 2014. On the savings side, it includes a €700m cut in the cost of paying public sector workers, Keenan flagged up, following layoffs since the crisis began. The cut to maternity pay is also proving unpopular. The Irish Independent has rounded up all the key tax and spending changes in today's Budget, along with measures that weren't touched: SOCIAL WELFARE Bereavement grant of €850 to families of dead people scrapped OAP telephone allowance of €9.50 a month scrapped Reduced dole payment for unemployed people under 26 Maternity benefit higher rate to be cut from €262 to 230 a week Phasing out of mortgage interest supplement for new applicants Technical changes to the invalidity pension Clawback from insurance companies on compensation payments Rent Supplement minimum contribution to be increased Child benefit for third and subsequent child down €10, as announced Mortgage Interest Relief to be phased out RTE subsidy for OAP TV licences to be reduced by €5m from €59m to €54m Normal dole payment safe Pension safe Free Travel safe Half rate carers allowance safe Respite Care grant safe HEALTH 35,000 over 70s to go from medical card to GP only card Income thresholds on medical cards for over 70s also to be tightened GP only medical card for all children under 5 Prescription charges to go up by €1 Cuts to hospital services DUTY CHANGES Wine to go up by 50c Pint, spirits and cigarettes to go up by 10c Cigarette sellers charge to go up 10 fold No excise duty on petrol and diesel expected EDUCATION Ending double payments in training schemes, where participants get two benefits College registration fees to go up by €250, as announced Pupil-Teacher-Ratio safe Private schools subsidy safe As rumoured, Brendan Howlin has announced that the Irish government will offer free GP care for all under 5s in Ireland. In another bright spot, Howlin also promised 1,250 new teachers. But these were rare spots as the minister for public affairs and reform outlined wider spending cuts to keep Ireland on track to exit its bailout. This included cuts to the unemployment benefit, and for those on maternity leave. Economist Megan Greene isn't convinced that Ireland can hit 2% GDP growth in 2014, as Michael Noonan predicted: Full details of the Irish budget are online here. Our Irish correspondent, Henry McDonald, sums up the key points from the Irish Budget. Michael Noonan has imposed ten cents extra on the price of a packet of cigarettes and the same figure of excise duty on pints of beer and cider. He has also decided to add an extra 50 cents on a bottle of wine. Noonan justified the hikes in alcohol duty with a mind to complaints from Ireland's pub, cafe and restaraunt owners by pointing out that he has frozen the 9% VAT rate in the overall hospitality sector. He stressed there would be no increase in direct taxation and no rise in the Universal Social Charge imposed during the fiscal crisis. Tax on interest gained from savings - the so called DIRT tax rate - would be increased to 41%, Noonan said. To signal the Fine Gael-Labour Coalition is prepared to impose some pain on the hated banking sector bailed out with billions of euro, Noonan said the banks would pay an annual levy of €150 to the exchequer per annum up to 2016. There was good news for Ireland's tourist sector and businesses experiencing growth this year such as Dublin Airport. The Finance Minister said the €3 euro tax on every flight would end in April “in the hope that airlines will open more routes into the country”. In a statement of defiance in the face of criticism from the German SPD, the Irish Finance Minister told the Dail there would be no change in Ireland's relatively low corporation tax rate. "The tax rate is settled policy. We are 100% committed to the 12.5% corporation tax rate. This will not change," he assured the parliament. The SPD in coalition talks with Angela Merkel in Berlin has demanded the next future German government led by her must ask the EU to review the Republic's corporation tax rate. The Social Democrats have argued that the low rate puts Ireland at an advantage over other EU states in terms of attracting foreign direct investment. Expect a battle between Dublin and Berlin ahead if the SPD gets its way and corporation tax is on the EU agenda. "The recovery is underway but there are still risks," Noonnan announced to the Dail in his final contribution. "We are well along the recovery path. Back in Dublin, Labour's Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Brendan Howlin, is explaining the expenditure changes in the 2014 Irish budget. It will include €1.6bn of spending cuts, he says (out of the €2.5bn total of austerity measures) He defends the deep cutbacks and tax rises of the last few years, saying there was no choice. And he also points out that the Irish budget has come under strain since the crisis began, citing the 200,000 increase in those seeking jobseekers benefits. Breaking away from Dublin... over in Washington, there are signs that Republicans in the House of Representatives are rebelling against plans for a breakthrough deal on the debt ceiling and a new budget . My US colleagues are liveblogging it here: House Republicans challenge bipartisan Senate deal to avert default – live We are well along the path to recovery, Noonan concludes, and this budget will help us finish the job. Noonan returns to the predicted primary surplus for 2014, saying it will help give the financial markets confidence in lending to Ireland. If a state cannot borrow at affordable rates, it cannot pay for public services, says Noonan. That's one of the key messages from the financial crisis. No tax increase on fuel or heating oil though. The Irish government is also imposing a levy on its banking sector, to raise €150m per year between 2014 and 2016. Noonan has raised alcohol and tobacco duties, putting 10 cents on a packet of 20 cigarettes, 10 cents on a pint of beer, and 50 cents on a bottle of wine. On growth, the Irish government expects growth of just 0.2% this year, rising to 2% in 2014. Onto the fiscal targets. Noonan said that the Irish deficit would be 7.3% this year, falling to 4.8% in 2014, and 2.9% in 2015. We have beaten our deficit targets to date, and a 4.8% deficit next year will also beat our targets, the finance minister explains. On Corporation Tax, Michael Noonan says the Irish government is committed to its 12.5% corporation tax. He acknowledged the international concern that multinationals are using Ireland to lower their tax bills, and said he would bring in changes to the finance mill to stop Irish companies being 'stateless'. Ireland want to be part of the solution to this global tax challenges, not part of the problem, Noonan said. but.... I want Ireland to play fair, and play to win Noonan also said the government will take steps to increase the housing stock in Ireland, to prevent a new housing bubble emerging. Michael Noonan wins approving noises by announcing he will extend the 9% special relief VAT rate for the hospitality sector -- the subject of a campaign. He is also cutting the air travel tax to zero - adding that he hopes Irish airlines will take advantage of this. From Dublin, Henry McDonald reports: There is a security cordon with two separate crush barriers manned by Gardai including officers on horseback leading up the Dail this afternoon. Wedged up against the barrier nearer to the parliament is only small eclectic banding of anti-austerity demonstrators ranging from Sinn Fein to a small band of far left groups. Molesworth Street which includes the main Irish passport office is eerily quiet ahead of the budget which is now being delivered. Is it just a coincidence that in the same street the European Commission office on Dublin also has a brand new silver crush barrier around the front of its headquarters? Noonan says his budget will include 25 'pro-jobs' measures. Noonan says some people would like to see more austerity this year, but says this is not acceptable -- quoting WB Yeats: Too long a sacrifice can make a stone of the heart. The Irish government will achieve a deficit of 4.8% in 2014, and a small primary surplus (discounting the cost of servicing Ireland's debts). Noonan confirms that the budget will include €2.5bn of tax rises and spending cuts. Noonan adds that the Irish economy is now on the road to recovery -- saying 300 new jobs are now being created. Finance minister Michael Noonan is starting to deliver the Irish budget now, blaming reckless polities from the previous government for causing the 'disaster' in Ireland. Here's the scene in the Irish parliament. Nearly time for Ireland's government to announce its budget for 2014. You can watch it live on RTE's website Heads-up: one of the City's best fund managers is stepping down next year to launch a new fund management firm. Neil Woodford, UK head of equities at Invesco Perpetual and one of the premier managers in the Square Mile, will leave in April. He said: I leave the company on good terms and remain fully committed to my fund management responsibilities at Invesco Perpetual until my departure. Walmart's chief executive, Mike Duke, says America's shoppers are also fretting about the US shutdown. fastfT has the quote from Duke, who was speaking at Walmart's annual meeting with USA analysts: It should come as no surprise that the government shutdown is on the mind of our US customers. as you would expect that we're following this situation very closely. Here's our take on the latest City investigation, into whether foreign exchange rates may have been secretly manipulated: Former Royal Bank of Scotland trader linked to currency market fixing Annalisa Piazza of Newedge Strategy says today's drop on the Empire State Factory index shows that US firms are worrying about the federal government shutdown. She writes: Concerns about the current fiscal negotiations and shutdown of the federal government offices (and possible effects on the real economy) clearly explain the decline in sentiment over the month. That said, the survey remains consistent with the idea of moderate growth in the district, without signs of robust acceleration in activity in the near term.... All in all, a decline in confidence is perfectly justified by the current uncertain fiscal scenario. Risks (albeit low) of a default of the US debt are partially incorporated in the current sentiment survey and we expect a technical correction to materialise once a final (or temporary) deal is found in Washington DC. Here's a rarity -- some economic data out of America. And it doesn't look too impressive. The New York Fed's Empire State Factory index, which monitors manufacturing conditions in the area, dropped to just +1.5 from +6.3 in September. That's means conditions improved, but at the lowest rate since May this year. Analysts expected a rise to +7. The drop was partly caused by deteriorating employment conditions (the employment sub-index slipped from 7.5 to 3.6). However, the new-orders measure picked up. "Hard to tell what this index is telling us," says Bloomberg 's economics editor Michael McKee as the news flashed up. He quickly homed in on a line that firms aren't seeking new credit because they can't see the demand. Not a great sign, with the US shutdown now eating into economic activity. Short-term US debt is rising in value in early New York trading, pushing down the interest rate on America's bonds. 15-Oct-2013 13:16 - U.S. TREASURY BILL RATES FALL ON SIGNS OF POSSIBLE U.S. FISCAL DEAL 15-Oct-2013 13:19 - INTEREST RATES ON U.S. T-BILL ISSUES DUE IN OCTOBER TO NOVEMBER FALL LOWEST IN A WEEK The yield on one-month US Treasury bills is down around 5 basis points at 0.2%. They mature around the time that America could default if it cannot reach a debt ceiling deal. RTE's Tony Connelly has full details of Wolfgang Schäuble's comments on the Irish banking sector: Seeing some reports from the Euro press pack that Germany's finance minister has dampened hopes that Irish banks could be retroactively recapitalised through Europe's new Stability Mechanism. The back story here is that Dublin 'took one for the t€am' by nationalising its toxic bank assets in 2009, at a time when there was no eurozone mechanism to provide bailout funds. That protected other eurozone banks from losses, so many feel that Ireland should be allowed to access the ESM. Germany isn't making it easy.... On his way into the last Cabinet meeting before today's budget, Irish finance minister Michael Noonan said the adjustments to the country's finances will take the Republic out of its "disastrous phase" that followed the boom that went bust. Noonan said: We want to position the country to exit the bailout so we can put this phase of Irish history behind us and build the economy and build the country going forward for everybody’s future. He added that the government's key aim - again with the accent on working families (the "coping classes") - was to “leave people with the bulk of their take home pay”. (via Henry McDonald in Dublin). Today's budget comes three days after prime minister Enda Kenny declared that Ireland's " economic emergency" will end in December (more here: Enda Kenny confirms December date for Ireland's bailout exit). Alan McQuaid, chief economist at Merrion Stockbrokers, commented (via Reuters): Growth momentum is picking up, with a possible carry over into 2014 Markets will probably see it as a final step towards exiting the bail-out. Greek government debt has also strengthened in value this morning, pushing down the yield on its 10-year bills to just 8.45% this morning, down from 8.68% last night. That's close to the highest level since Greece restructured its debts in February 2012. The price of Greek bonds maturing in 2030 has hit a post-default high. This comes after Greece finance minister, Yannis Stournaras, and the ECB's Jorg Asmussen disagreed over the size of Greece's funding shortfall, and whether it needs to implement more austerity in 2014. The Wall Street Journal published the full details last night. Here's a flavour: "First and foremost, [it] is important that they [Greece] will close the significant fiscal gap that is there for next year," Mr. Asmussen told reporters on his way into a meeting of euro-zone finance minister. Mr. Stournaras, however, flatly rejected the claim that there is a "significant fiscal gap" in the country's 2014 budget. "In our opinion, there is no fiscal gap," he told reporters, adding that Mr. Asmussen didn't repeat this claim inside the meeting. It's been a good morning in Europe's stock markets, thanks to optimism that the US Congress can agree a debt ceiling increase and a budget for 2014 in time to avoid a disastrous default (see my opening posts for the backstory). Germany's DAX index is at a new lifetime high, while the French CAC has hit levels not seen since 2008. The FTSE 100 is at its highest so far this month. Only Italy, where the government is locked in discussions over its own 2014 budget, failed to rally. The relief came after Senate leaders declared last night they'd made real progress towards a deal. Toby Morris, senior sales trader at CMC Markets, said investors were keen to get into equities before a US deal is announced. This morning's strong German ZEW confidence reading was also cheering the City. Morris also pointed out that an index of small US firms hit a record high yesterday: Either markets have absolute faith that politicians in the US will ultimately do the right thing, or have simply become numb to big macro shocks in the last few years, but to see the US Russell small cap index posting fresh all time high’s as a deadline dubbed “financial apocalypse” sits so close seems dangerous to say the least. Here's the latest prices in Europe: FTSE 100: up 60 points at 6568, + 1% German DAX: up 67 points at 8791, +0.77% French CAC: up 26 points at4249, +0.6% Italian FTSE MIB: flat Spanish IBEX: up 46 points at 9743, + 0.5% A US debt ceiling deal will, as the cliche has it, kick the can down the road. The question is, how far. Sebastien Galy of Société Générale comments: Kick it like Beckham..... The eternal question is whether it is his left foot or the right one. The outlines of the senate debt ceiling deal suggest such a kick down the road with the main work left to a committee (tax code..). I leave you the judge of which foot they used. Given the success of such committees, it is a delaying tactic suggesting a series of hard fought battles lie ahead for the incumbent administration. The UK government has denied that this morning's increase in UK house prices to a record high (according to the ONS) means its new Help to Buy scheme is a mistake. A HM Treasury spokesperson said: We’re encouraged to see signs that house prices are recovering from a low base alongside the wider economy. However, the government understands that the housing and mortgage markets are yet to return to their long run levels, leaving too many people – especially first-time buyers – struggling to afford historically high level of deposits. That’s why the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee is a vital tool to give young people the same opportunity to get a foot on the property ladder as previous generations. Should also flag up an interesting blogpost on FT Alphaville by Dan McCrum this morning, showing how London (and UK) house prices are some way below their pre-crisis peak once you adjust for inflation: Wait what, the enormous unnoticed collapse in London property prices It's an important day in Ireland, where the government is preparing to announce its budget for 2014. The broad message is expected to be another year of spending cuts and fiscal squeeze, but there could be a few measures to help the public Ministers are already arguing that today's budget will help those trying to cope with Ireland's long austerity drive. From Dublin, Henry McDonald sets the scene: Rising star in the main party of government, Fine Gael, Brian Hayes sets the tone for today's budget by portraying it as a range of measures to help the "coping classes" of Ireland. The Junior Minister's choice of phrase echoes Ed Miliband's reference to the "Squeezed middle", the middle classes and the working poor, who have continued to work and pay their taxes in the midst of the economic crash, the age of austerity and the cost of living crisis. But there will be as much as George Osborne as Ed Balls or Miliband in today's budget delivered this afternoon in the Dail by two ministers: Fine Gael's Finance Minister Michael Noonon and Labour's Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Brendan Howlin. In an appeal to the "coping classes" especially those with small children the government will announce its well flagged up plan to give free GP care to all under 5s in Ireland. This measure is seen as a major concession to the Labour Party in the Coalition and will be trumpeted as one designed to help young, working families AKA the "coping classes" AKA "the squeezed middle." Noonan will reveal a range of cuts totalling €2.5bn including a hefty reduction in unemployment benefit to the jobless under the age of 25. Their jobseeker's will be slashed from the current €144 per week to €100. And the age of eligibility for the full social payment of €188 (still one of the most generous in the whole of the EU) per week will be raised to the age of 26. Prescription charges for medicines will be raised from €1.50 to €2.50. Citizens digging deep to pay for a range of medications in the Republic will be looking enviously across the border to Northern Ireland where their counterparts pay nothing for prescriptions. In what could be a political gamble given that they are the one section of the Irish population inclined to get out and vote, the Fine Gael-Labour coalition have put pressure for the first time in years on Ireland's pensioners. This interest group, normally immune from budget cuts, will experience some cost cutting measures. One in ten of all pensioners over 70 will lose their full medical card entitling them to free health care. A subsidy of €114 per year to pay pensioners' telephone bills will also be scrapped while a death grant to pay for funerals - worth €850 until today - will be abolished. Irish pensioners however will remain among the most well off OAP's anywhere in the EU because they will continue to enjoy free travel (north and south of the border), a free TV license and subsidies to their gas and electricity bills. Overall there is expected to be around €900 million raised in new taxes to reach today's budget target of savings. Henry adds that the debate on the budget, which begins with Michael Noonan's speech to the Dail around 2.30pm, is likely to last until the early evening. From China, chancellor George Osborne tweets that the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited will soon become the first Chinese mainland bank to sell a renminbi bond in the City. The news comes as Osborne continues to lead a ministerial delegation to China. Overnight, the two countries also announced plans to allow Chinese banks to open branches in London, an agreement to allow sterling to be traded directly against the renminbi, and a £8.2bn quote for UK banks to invest in Chinese securities. More here. The gold price has hit a new three month low today, shedding $18 from its early-morning high to $1,257 per ounce. That could be people moving out of gold and into shares (Europe's markets are still up), and also reflects the US dollar rising against most currencies this morning (so you should need fewer dollars to buy a lump of gold). Ishaq Siddiqi, market strategist at ETX Capital, summed up the markets: Equities looking perky, US dollar gaining lost ground versus other currencies, gold reversing previous session gains... and bonds falling out of favour on risk-on mood currently sweeping price-action. US lawmakers are finally making headway on a deal to avert financial destruction before Thursday’s D-day deadline, propping up market sentiment in overnight trade across US and Asian share markets, pulling up Europe this morning. Gold's been volatile for a while, driven in part by speculation on when the Federal Reserve will ease its stimulus programme. If the progress in Washington does lead to a deal, that might help to put Fed 'tapering' back on the agenda (or put another way, it's hard to see the Fed ending its money printing if the US is flirting with default). Around half the trades in Royal Mail so far today are small investors selling their allocation of 227 shares, according to IG's David Jones. He also sees signs that traders are taking the opportunity to 'short' Royal Mail -- betting that it will drop in the coming days. Economic confidence in Germany has hit its highest level since April 2010, as Europe's powerhouse remained calm in the face of US budget and debt ceiling deadlock. The monthly ZEW index jumped to 52.8, much better than forecasts of 49.6. ZEW, the German think tank, said 'good early indicators' in the domestic and eurozone economy were had driven sentiment. Without the problems in the US, the reading could have been even higher, it added. Here's more news flashes from Reuters: 15-Oct-2013 10:11 - ZEW ECONOMIST - RECESSION IN EURO ZONE IS BOTTOMING OUT 15-Oct-2013 10:12 - ZEW ECONOMIST - EURO ZONE CRISIS IS OVER, FOR THE MOMENT In other UK economic news, house prices in the UK have hit a new record high. The ONS's monthly house price index increased to 185.8, beating the previous peak set in January 2008. That means the average price of a house or flat in the UK is now £247,000 - with London and the South East leading the way. Sky's Ed Conway tweets the key points: While Capital Economic's Matthew Pointon urges caution: Rising education costs also helped keep UK inflation at 2.7% in September. The ONS reports that they rose by 21.4% compared with a year ago, the highest annual rise in education prices since records began in 1997. Here's James Knightley of ING's take: Fuel was the main dampening influence with the YoY rate for this component dropping to -1.6%. However, food price inflation rose in YoY terms while air fares also made a big upwards contribution and education costs, which were up 21.4%YoY, saw the fastest annual rise since records began. This graph shows how CPI inflation has been volatile over the last decade, and hasn't hit the Bank of England's 2% target in close to four years. The pound rose on the news that UK inflation was higher than forecast - gaining a quarter of a cent to above $1.60. And Britain's borrowing costs have also increased. The yield (or interest rate) on 10-year gilts up 0.05 percentage points to 2.802%, the highest since September 25th, as the price of the bond falls. Traders may be anticipating that higher inflation will force the Bank of England to raise interest rates earlier than planned, and that there's even less chance of another quantitative easing (bond-buying) programme. Just in - UK inflation was unchanged last month, defying expectations that the rising cost of living would ease. The Consumer Prices index came in at 2.7% on an annual basis in September. Economists had predicted that CPI would ease to 2.6%. Price rose by 0.4% on a month-on-month basis, the Office for National Statistics said. The ONS reported that the largest upward contribution came from air fares, though this was offset by a downward contribution from petrol and diesel prices. The Retail Prices Index edged down from 3.3% to 3.2%. The ONS also reported that Food and non-alcoholic beverage prices are 4.3% higher than a year ago, while alcoholic beverages were up 5.4%. More to follow.... Looking at Royal Mail again, a lot of the trades passing through the City this morning are for exactly 227 shares: That's members of the public selling the shares they received last week, banking a profit of over £300. Here's our news story on the surprise news this morning that Angela Ahrendts is leaving Burberry for a new senior role at Apple: Burberry chief Angela Ahrendts leaves for new job at Apple In the eurozone, European Council president Herman Van Rompuy has reportedly declared that the existential threat to the euro is "behind us". Van Rompuy also told an audience in Cyprus that the EU will continue to stand by Cyprus as it implements its bailout programme (which has already helped push it into a steep recession). He's been holding a press conference with president Nicos Anastasiades, from where his staff have tweeted a picture: This morning's rally has pushed Germany's DAX to a record high, in fact, while France's CAC is at a five-year high. All Europe's major stock indices are higher this morning, on hopes that the progress made in Washington last night will translate into a debt ceiling and budget deal. Here's a snapshot, with the FTSE 100 gaining 0.6% , German's DAX up nearly 0.5% and the French, Spanish and Italian markets rising a more modest 0.2-0.3%. Monex Capital reckons that Wall Street may open flat, while traders watch for a real breakthrough on Capitol Hill: Market sentiment appears to be turning once again with traders becoming increasingly optimistic that a solution will be found to the impasse in Washington before the money essentially runs out on Thursday. Asian equities have been given some support off the back of this especially through the latter part of the session and US futures are now pointing towards a relatively flat start at the open, although it's obviously worth bearing in mind that some lawmakers may want to string this out until quite literally the eleventh hour. More reaction to the City losing Angela Ahrendts to Apple, on a morning in which Burberry also reported a 17% jump in underlying retail revenues. Retail analyst Nick Bubb: A year ago, Burberry caused some consternation by warning that an unexpected slump in Chinese tourist footfall had hit its Retail sales last autumn, so today’s pre-close trading update was expected to strike a more cheerful tone and it is, with Retail sales up by 17%, but the big surprise is the news that the CEO, Angela Ahrendts, is off to join Apple and Christopher Bailey is taking over! Richard Hunter, Head of Equities at Hargreaves Lansdown Stockbrokers: Whatever the ramifications may be, it seems that the she leaves the company in good shape. Total revenues for the period were up 14%, with retail sales also rising on the back of a strong contribution from the Asian Pacific area. Revenues were also robust in Europe and the Middle East, whilst the Americas also enjoyed high single digit growth. Indeed, the company’s geographical diversification continues to underpin its performance, whilst the careful investment strategy is reaping rewards. Less positively, the recent comments of the departing CEO on the longer term prospects for China were unsettling, whilst of course the change at the helm will provide some caution in regards to continuity. In addition, the company’s very existence is one at the mercy of fashion, and there are no signs that the fierceness of competition is about to subside. On Royal Mail, MPs are reportedly planning to haul the government's advisors in to justify floating Royal Mail at a valuation of £3.3bn. Sky's Mark Kleinman has the story: A panel of MPs is poised to extend a probe into the privatisation of Royal Mail by summoning the City bankers who advised ministers on the sell-off to give evidence. Sky News has learnt that some members of the Business, Innovation and Skills Select Committee (BIS) want to interview executives from the syndicate of banks responsible for pricing the initial public offering (IPO) at 330p-per-share. This morning's share price rise values Royal Mail at £4.85bn.... It's the first morning of full trading in Royal Mail shares, and they're climbing. Shares in Royal Mail have risen another 10p to 485p, which is a gain of 2% today -- or 47% on the 330p at which Britain's postal service was floated last week. Members of the public are looking at a £300 profit if they sell now. City commentator David Buik points out that 500 big investors were left with nothing in last week's hugely over-subscribed IPO, so may be keen to buy shares this morning, even though a strike ballot is looming. Burberry shares have opened 5.5% lower following the news that CEO Angela Ahrendts is leaving to join Apple. Europe's stock markets are up in early trading, with the FTSE 100 gaining 42 points (or 0.6%). Burberry haven't traded yet, though..... Other European markets are also higher. Round-up to follow.... Big news in the City this morning -- Burberry chief executive Angela Ahrendts is stepping down from the fashion chain, for a new job at Apple. Ahrendts, who has been hailed for driving's Burberry success in the eight years as chief executive, will take up a new role as Apple's Senior Vice President of Retail and Online Stores. Apple's Tim Cook sounds delighted: She shares our values and our focus on innovation, and she places the same strong emphasis as we do on the customer experience. She has shown herself to be an extraordinary leader throughout her career and has a proven track record. It certainly looks like a great hire for Apple. It means the City is losing one of its more successful bosses, and also cuts the number of female CEOs in the FTSE 100 to just two. Burberry are promoting chief creative offices Christopher Bailey to replace Ahrendts. Sir John Peace, Chairman of Burberry, said he has no doubt Bailey will "keep Burberry on the forefront creatively, digitally and financially". No pressure.... Here's the Apple statement..... and here's the Burberry one. Senate majority leader Harry Reid fuelled hopes of a deal last night when he told reporters that he and minority leader Mitch McConnell had made "tremendous progress" towards a deal. My US colleague Ed Pilkington rounded up the state of play in Washington last night: Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority and minority leaders, held two lengthy meetings on Monday in an attempt to nail down terms of a possible compromise. The urgency of the talks was matched by the scale of the crisis facing them: unless an agreement is reached on raising America’s borrowing limit by midnight on Thursday, the US will begin to default on its payments, with possible global economic ramifications. Obama postponed a 3pm White House gathering of congressional leaders to give McConnell and Reid extra time to fine-tune a package. "My hope is that a spirit of co-operation will move us forward over the next few hours," the president said earlier in the day, adding the ominous note that "if we don't start making some real progress in the House and the Senate, and if Republicans aren't willing to set aside some of their partisan concerns in order to do what's right for the country, we stand a good chance of defaulting." More here: Senate leaders close in on debt ceiling deal after lengthy talks on Capitol Hill Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events across the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and the business world. European stock markets are expected to rise this morning, on hopes that American politicians can finally agree a deal to raise the US debt ceiling and pass a new budget for 2014. Last night, Republican and Democratic leaders in the Senate were racing to agree a compromise that would extend the US debt limit beyond the $16.7trn limit which it could hit on Thursday. Talks at the White House were postponed until today, to allow Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority and minority leaders, more time to carve a plan. Although there's no guarantee of a deal, the sense of renewed urgency is likely to push shares higher in Europe. Here's IG's early calls: Ahead of the European open we are calling the FTSE at 6540 +33, DAX 8762 +39, CAC 4242 +20, IBEX 9753 +43 and MIB 19006 +89 Asian markets have already welcomed the signs of progress, with the South Korean market up 1.2% and the Australian market gaining 1%. But the deadlock of the last fortnight (this is day 15 of the federal government shutdown) has also left many analysts speculating about the long-term damage caused to America's dominant place in the financial markets. I'll round up the latest comments shortly. The agenda Also coming up today -- the Irish government will announce its own budget for 2014, the seventh 'austerity budget' in a row. That comes at 4.30pm BST. EU finance ministers are gathering for an ECOFIN meeting in Luxembourg, following yesterday's eurogroup gathering. fields.body:
5.02pm BST

PS: one last line from Dublin, from Henry McDonald:

There was some pre-Hallowe'en ghoulish reaction to one aspect of the budget cuts from Fianna Fail, the main opposition party in Ireland.

The party's finance spokesman Michael McGrath warned that "even the dead aren't safe from this Government."

McGrath was referring to the measure in the budget which removes the €850 burial grant for some pensioners. 

4.59pm BST

Closing summary, as European markets closer higher

Amid the confusion in Washington, European stock markets ended higher. Traders still think there's going to be a deal - despite the disfunctionality in Congress.

The FTSE 100 finished 41 points higher at 6,549, up 0.64%, led by mining giant Rio Tinto (with Burberry bringing up the rear, down 7.6% following CEO Angela Ahrendts' exit to join Apple).

Elsewhere on the stock market, Royal Mail shares finished 14p higher at 489p, a 48% jump on the float price.

The German Dax closed at a new record high, up 0.9%, while the French CAC closed at its highest level since 2008.

And that's a good time to stop.

Live coverage of the Irish budget starts here

There's analysis of Michael Noonan's statement here (from Henry)...and an explanation of how pensioners and the young unemployed will be hit hard.

There's a list of key points here.

Stay tuned to our US liveblog for developments in Washington. Could there be a deal by morning?.....

We'll find out by tomorrow. Until then, thanks, and goodnight. GW

4.43pm BST

Twists and turns in Washington this afternoon, with House Republicans proposing their own solution to the debt ceiling/budget deadlock, only to see it slapped down as a "partisan attempt to appease" the Tea Party by the White House.

In the last few minutes, Senate majority leaders Harry Reid just declared that the House's proposal won't get through the Senate. Clearly a deal isn't agreed -- we'll be tracking it all through the day (and night?) here:

House Republicans challenge bipartisan Senate deal to avert default – live

4.33pm BST

Henry also points out that finance minister Michael Noonan hasn't bowed to pressure from Germany over Ireland's corporation tax rate:

In defiance of criticism from the German SPD, Noonan told the Dail there would be no change in Ireland's relatively low corporation tax rate.

"The tax rate is settled policy. We are 100% committed to the 12.5% corporation tax rate. This will not change," he said.

The SPD in coalition talks with Angela Merkel has demanded the next German government led by her must ask the EU to review the Republic's corporation tax rate. The Social Democrats have argued that the low rate puts Ireland at an advantage over other EU states in terms of attracting foreign direct investment.

There was one significant change, though. As I flagged up at 2.55pm, Noonan did promise to stop companies registered in Ireland from being 'stateless' for tax purposes. 

4.28pm BST

Henry McDonald: Pensioners and young unemployed suffer

Dublin correspondent Henry McDonald flags up that this year's budget is a blow to Irish pensioners: 

One in ten of all pensioners over 70 will lose their full medical card entitling them to free health care. A subsidy of €114 per year to pay pensioners' telephone bills will also be scrapped while a death grant to pay for funerals - worth €850 - will be abolished.

The move on pensioners could be a major political gamble given that they are one sector of the population guaranteed to get out and vote in elections.

The Finance Minister also risked alienating pensioners, who make up a large proportion of savers, over his decision to increase tax on interest gained from savings - the so called DIRT tax rate – which is to be raised to 41%.

Those unemployed under the age of 25 would also bear the brunt of the cuts with jobseeker's allowance being slashed from the current €144 per week to €100. The age of eligibility for the full social payment of €188 (still one of the most generous in the whole of the EU) will be raised to the age of 26.

4.23pm BST

Some reaction to the changes in Irish budget from Twitter:

4.16pm BST

On RTE, Brendan Keenan of the Irish Independent explained that increasing the duty on beer (10c), cigarettes (10c) and wine (50c); and the €150m/year bank levy, will provide a decent chunk of the revenue increases for 2014.

On the savings side, it includes a €700m cut in the cost of paying public sector workers, Keenan flagged up, following layoffs since the crisis began.

The cut to maternity pay is also proving unpopular.

Updated at 4.17pm BST

4.05pm BST

Irish budget: the changes

The Irish Independent has rounded up all the key tax and spending changes in today's Budget, along with measures that weren't touched:

SOCIAL WELFARE

Bereavement grant of €850 to families of dead people scrapped

OAP telephone allowance of €9.50 a month scrapped

Reduced dole payment for unemployed people under 26

Maternity benefit higher rate to be cut from €262 to 230 a week

Phasing out of mortgage interest supplement for new applicants

Technical changes to the invalidity pension

Clawback from insurance companies on compensation payments

Rent Supplement minimum contribution to be increased

Child benefit for third and subsequent child down €10, as announced

Mortgage Interest Relief to be phased out

RTE subsidy for OAP TV licences to be reduced by €5m from €59m to €54m

Normal dole payment safe

Pension safe

Free Travel safe

Half rate carers allowance safe

Respite Care grant safe

HEALTH

35,000 over 70s to go from medical card to GP only card

Income thresholds on medical cards for over 70s also to be tightened

GP only medical card for all children under 5

Prescription charges to go up by €1

Cuts to hospital services

DUTY CHANGES

Wine to go up by 50c

Pint, spirits and cigarettes to go up by 10c

Cigarette sellers charge to go up 10 fold

No excise duty on petrol and diesel expected

EDUCATION

Ending double payments in training schemes, where participants get two benefits

College registration fees to go up by €250, as announced

Pupil-Teacher-Ratio safe

Private schools subsidy safe

3.50pm BST

Key points from Brendan Howlin

As rumoured, Brendan Howlin has announced that the Irish government will offer free GP care for all under 5s in Ireland.

In another bright spot, Howlin also promised 1,250 new teachers.

But these were rare spots as the minister for public affairs and reform outlined wider spending cuts to keep Ireland on track to exit its bailout.

This included cuts to the unemployment benefit, and for those on maternity leave.

3.32pm BST

Economist Megan Greene isn't convinced that Ireland can hit 2% GDP growth in 2014, as Michael Noonan predicted:

3.28pm BST

Full details of the Irish budget are online here.

3.26pm BST

Irish budget - the key points

Our Irish correspondent, Henry McDonald, sums up the key points from the Irish Budget.

Michael Noonan has imposed ten cents extra on the price of a packet of cigarettes and the same figure of excise duty on pints of beer and cider. He has also decided to add an extra 50 cents on a bottle of wine.

Noonan justified the hikes in alcohol duty with a mind to complaints from Ireland's pub, cafe and restaraunt owners by pointing out that he has frozen the 9% VAT rate in the overall hospitality sector. 

He stressed there would be no increase in direct taxation and no rise in the Universal Social Charge imposed during the fiscal crisis. 

Tax on interest gained from savings - the so called DIRT tax rate - would be increased to 41%, Noonan said.

To signal the Fine Gael-Labour Coalition is prepared to impose some pain on the hated banking sector bailed out with billions of euro, Noonan said the banks would pay an annual levy of €150 to the exchequer per annum up to 2016. 

There was good news for Ireland's tourist sector and businesses experiencing growth this year such as Dublin Airport. The Finance Minister said the €3 euro tax on every flight would end in April “in the hope that airlines will open more routes into the country”.

In a statement of defiance in the face of criticism from the German SPD, the Irish Finance Minister told the Dail there would be no change in Ireland's relatively low corporation tax rate.

"The tax rate is settled policy. We are 100% committed to the 12.5% corporation tax rate. This will not change," he assured the parliament. 

The SPD in coalition talks with Angela Merkel in Berlin has demanded the next future German government led by her must ask the EU to review the Republic's corporation tax rate. The Social Democrats have argued that the low rate puts Ireland at an advantage over other EU states in terms of attracting foreign direct investment. 

Expect a battle between Dublin and Berlin ahead if the SPD gets its way and corporation tax is on the EU agenda.

"The recovery is underway but there are still risks," Noonnan announced to the Dail in his final contribution. "We are well along the recovery path.

3.20pm BST

Back in Dublin, Labour's Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Brendan Howlin, is explaining the expenditure changes in the 2014 Irish budget.

It will include €1.6bn of spending cuts, he says (out of the €2.5bn total of austerity measures)

He defends the deep cutbacks and tax rises of the last few years, saying there was no choice.

And he also points out that the Irish budget has come under strain since the crisis began, citing the 200,000 increase in those seeking jobseekers benefits.

3.10pm BST

Breaking away from Dublin... over in Washington, there are signs that Republicans in the House of Representatives are rebelling against plans for a breakthrough deal on the debt ceiling and a new budget .

My US colleagues are liveblogging it here:

House Republicans challenge bipartisan Senate deal to avert default – live

3.07pm BST

We are well along the path to recovery, Noonan concludes, and this budget will help us finish the job.

3.06pm BST

Noonan returns to the predicted primary surplus for 2014, saying it will help give the financial markets confidence in lending to Ireland.

If a state cannot borrow at affordable rates, it cannot pay for public services, says Noonan. That's one of the key messages from the financial crisis. 

3.04pm BST

No tax increase on fuel or heating oil though.

3.01pm BST

The Irish government is also imposing a levy on its banking sector, to raise €150m per year between 2014 and 2016.

Updated at 3.25pm BST

3.01pm BST

Noonan has raised alcohol and tobacco duties, putting 10 cents on a packet of 20 cigarettes, 10 cents on a pint of beer, and 50 cents on a bottle of wine.

2.59pm BST

On growth, the Irish government expects growth of just 0.2% this year, rising to 2% in 2014.

2.57pm BST

Onto the fiscal targets. Noonan said that the Irish deficit would be 7.3% this year, falling to 4.8% in 2014, and 2.9% in 2015.

We have beaten our deficit targets to date, and a 4.8% deficit next year will also beat our targets, the finance minister explains.

2.55pm BST

On Corporation Tax, Michael Noonan says the Irish government is committed to its 12.5% corporation tax.

He acknowledged the international concern that multinationals are using Ireland to lower their tax bills, and said he would bring in changes to the finance mill to stop Irish companies being 'stateless'.

Ireland want to be part of the solution to this global tax challenges, not part of the problem, Noonan said.

but....

I want Ireland to play fair, and play to win

2.51pm BST

Noonan also said the government will take steps to increase the housing stock in Ireland, to prevent a new housing bubble emerging.

2.49pm BST

Michael Noonan wins approving noises by announcing he will extend the 9% special relief VAT rate for the hospitality sector -- the subject of a campaign. 

He is also cutting the air travel tax to zero - adding that he hopes Irish airlines will take advantage of this.

2.42pm BST

Tight security in Dublin

From Dublin, Henry McDonald reports:

There is a security cordon with two separate crush barriers manned by Gardai including officers on horseback leading up the Dail this afternoon.

Wedged up against the barrier nearer to the parliament is only small eclectic banding of anti-austerity demonstrators ranging from Sinn Fein to a small band of far left groups. The New York Fed's Empire State Factory index, which monitors manufacturing conditions in the area, dropped to just +1.5 from +6.3 in September. That's means conditions improved, but at the lowest rate since May this year.

Analysts expected a rise to +7.

The drop was partly caused by deteriorating employment conditions (the employment sub-index slipped from 7.5 to 3.6). However, the new-orders measure picked up.

"Hard to tell what this index is telling us," says Bloomberg 's economics editor Michael McKee as the news flashed up. He quickly homed in on a line that firms aren't seeking new credit because they can't see the demand.

On his way into the last Cabinet meeting before today's budget, Irish finance minister Michael Noonan said the adjustments to the country's finances will take the Republic out of its "disastrous phase" that followed the boom that went bust. 

Noonan said:

We want to position the country to exit the bailout so we can put this phase of Irish history behind us and build the economy and build the country going forward for everybody’s future.

He added that the government's key aim - again with the accent on working families (the "coping classes") - was to “leave people with the bulk of their take home pay”. (via Henry McDonald in Dublin).

Growth momentum is picking up, with a possible carry over into 2014

Greek government debt has also strengthened in value this morning, pushing down the yield on its 10-year bills to just 8.45% this morning, down from 8.68% last night.

"First and foremost, [it] is important that they [Greece] will close the significant fiscal gap that is there for next year," Mr. Asmussen told reporters on his way into a meeting of euro-zone finance minister.

Germany's DAX index is at a new lifetime high, while the French CAC has hit levels not seen since 2008. The FTSE 100 is at its highest so far this month.

Irish austerity budget this afternoon

It's an important day in Ireland, where the government is preparing to announce its budget for 2014.

The broad message is expected to be another year of spending cuts and fiscal squeeze, but there could be a few measures to help the public 

Ministers are already arguing that today's budget will help those trying to cope with Ireland's long austerity drive.

From Dublin, Henry McDonald sets the scene:

Rising star in the main party of government, Fine Gael, Brian Hayes sets the tone for today's budget by portraying it as a range of measures to help the "coping classes" of Ireland.

The Junior Minister's choice of phrase echoes Ed Miliband's reference to the "Squeezed middle", the middle classes and the working poor, who have continued to work and pay their taxes in the midst of the economic crash, the age of austerity and the cost of living crisis. 

But there will be as much as George Osborne as Ed Balls or Miliband in today's budget delivered this afternoon in the Dail by two ministers: Fine Gael's Finance Minister Michael Noonon and Labour's Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Brendan Howlin. 

In an appeal to the "coping classes" especially those with small children the government will announce its well flagged up plan to give free GP care to all under 5s in Ireland. This measure is seen as a major concession to the Labour Party in the Coalition and will be trumpeted as one designed to help young, working families AKA the "coping classes" AKA "the squeezed middle."

Noonan will reveal a range of cuts totalling €2.5bn including a hefty reduction in unemployment benefit to the jobless under the age of 25. Their jobseeker's will be slashed from the current €144 per week to €100. And the age of eligibility for the full social payment of €188 (still one of the most generous in the whole of the EU) per week will be raised to the age of 26. 

Prescription charges for medicines will be raised from €1.50 to €2.50. Citizens digging deep to pay for a range of medications in the Republic will be looking enviously across the border to Northern Ireland where their counterparts pay nothing for prescriptions. 

In what could be a political gamble given that they are the one section of the Irish population inclined to get out and vote, the Fine Gael-Labour coalition have put pressure for the first time in years on Ireland's pensioners. This interest group, normally immune from budget cuts, will experience some cost cutting measures. One in ten of all pensioners over 70 will lose their full medical card entitling them to free health care. A subsidy of €114 per year to pay pensioners' telephone bills will also be scrapped while a death grant to pay for funerals - worth €850 until today - will be abolished. 

Irish pensioners however will remain among the most well off OAP's anywhere in the EU because they will continue to enjoy free travel (north and south of the border), a free TV license and subsidies to their gas and electricity bills. 

Overall there is expected to be around €900 million raised in new taxes to reach today's budget target of savings.

webTitle: George Osborne has to get to grips with inflation in the run-up to 2015 election

fields.standfirst: Price rises are set to outstrip pay rises well into the future, and the squeeze on incomes poses a real problem for the chancellor
fields.body:
Higher than expected inflation is a problem for George Osborne. He needs upward pressure on the cost of living to abate so that the squeeze on real incomes comes to an end well before the next election in May 2015. The latest official data shows that the moment when wages start growing more quickly than prices is still some way off.

At present, pay is going up by just over 1% while inflation as measured by the consumer prices index is rising at an annual rate of 2.7%. The City had expected a small fall last month to 2.6% but dearer food put paid to that. September's CPI is used to uprate pensions, so the elderly will benefit from the failure of inflation to fall – but only by 10p a week. Don't spend it all at once.

Apart from one relatively brief period in 2009, inflation has now been above the government's 2% target for six years. Rising global food and energy prices have something to do with this, but even so inflation in the UK is higher than in either the US or the European Union. Prices have proved relatively sticky in the UK; inflation has come down from its recent peak of just over 5% but it has been a slow process. For most of the past year CPI inflation has been in a range from 2.7%-2.9%.

Were this trend to persist, it would put the Bank of England in difficulties. When Threadneedle Street issued its forward guidance on interest rates in September, it said borrowing costs would remain at 0.5% at least until unemployment came down to 7% but made the pledge subject to three "knockouts". One involved the inflation rate: the Bank said it might have to move earlier if the cost of living was forecast to be above 2.5% in 18-24 months' time.

Neither the Bank nor the City see this as an immediate danger. The hope is that inflation will come down over the coming months because increases in food and energy bills will be lower this year than they were in 2012. But there is no prospect – as seemed possible a couple of months ago – that inflation will be back to 2% by the end of the year. That means that the pressure on living standards will persist, helping to explain why the overnment has been so keen to limit rail fare increases and to freeze petrol duty.

The struggle for many households to make ends meet means that, with one proviso, it seems unlikely there will be a surge in inflation even at a time when the economy is in recovery. That proviso is that the UK avoids a housing bubble.

webTitle: Royal Mail boss Moya Greene calls for protection from strikes

fields.standfirst: Chief executive's comments on first day of official share trading come as CWU union prepares to announce plans for industrial action
fields.body:
Royal Mail boss Moya Greene has called for "protections" from strikes as more than 100,000 postal workers prepare to announce plans for industrial action that could take place as soon as 23 October.

In an interview to mark Royal Mail's first official day as a public company, Greene said: "We need to start thinking about what sort of protections do we need as a company from our people, from what has been probably too quick an approach to resort to industrial action.

"I just think we need to look at alternative ways to resolve disputes," she told ITV News.

Greene's comments come as the Communication Workers Union (CWU) prepares to announce the result of a strike ballot on Wednesday.

The CWU, which represents more than 115,000 of Royal Mail's 150,000 employees, said it was "confident" that its members will vote on Wednesday for industrial action.

It is understood that the union has already made tentative plans for days of disruption in the run-up to Christmas.

Dave Ward, the CWU's deputy general secretary, said: "The Royal Mail share price has soared further today, bringing more proof that the company was undervalued by the government's City mates.

"The taxpayer has lost over £1bn already in this bungled fire sale of a cherished national institution. Postal workers cannot trade their shares for three years and they are far more concerned about their jobs than the share price. We're confident our members will return a yes vote in tomorrow's ballot result for strike action, strengthening our position to secure a deal on protecting jobs, services and terms and conditions in the company."

Royal Mail's shares have soared by 44% since the government privatised the 500-year-old company on Friday.

The share price spike means the 690,000 people who managed to buy a stake in the company have made paper profits of more than £300.

It also means the government could have collected at least more than £800m more for the taxpayer if it had sold the shares at 450p rather than 330p. The shares are currently changing hands at 481p.

Adrian Bailey, the Labour chair of the business department select committee, said the share price surge "vindicated" concerns the committee raised when it questioned the business secretary, Vince Cable, last week.

"At the meeting last week it's fair to say that members of the committee had one view and the secretary of state had another," Bailey said. "The share price movements have vindicated the concerns of the committee members. Let's see where the price settles."

Bailey said the committee will also call Lazard, the investment bank that advised the government on how to price Royal Mail, to answer questions about its valuation advice.

The National Audit Office, the public spending watchdog, and the public accounts committee will also investigate allegations that Royal Mail was sold too cheaply.

webTitle: Royal Mail investors struggle to cash in as sellers swamp official trading service

fields.standfirst: Share dealers Equiniti overloaded as thousands rush to book £300-plus profit on privatised firm's first official day of trading
fields.body:
Thousands of Royal Mail investors have been unable to sell their shares after the government's official trading service struggled under the pressure of tens of thousands of people trying to cash in their stakes, which have increased in value by 44%.

Investors who bought their shares directly from the government have struggled to place sell orders with the official Equiniti share-dealing service over the phone and others have yet to receive official notification required to sell online.

One investor trying to sell the 227 shares he was allocated in the flotation said he had redialled the 0845 268-8405 number "about 100 times" but been unable to get through.

Another investor tweeted: "Your phone lines are engaged and have been for hours. Online trade requires code sent through post (2days)."

Also on Twitter, another investor said: "Took me 400 attempts to get through to #equiniti Royal Mail sale line. Price dropped 12p in the 1 1/2 hours it took. #arseholes."

A spokesman for Equiniti said the company's phone lines had been swamped by sellers and apologised to people who had experienced difficulties. He said the company was urgently trying to fix the problem.

The government has warned that it could take up to 48 hours for emails detailing share allocations to be sent to all of the 690,000 investors who bought 227 shares in the flotation. Details in the emails are required for online selling.

Some investors are desperate to cash in their shares, which have soared in value by more than £300 since Friday.

Royal Mail shares hit a high of 490p in early trading on Tuesday, a 48% increase on the government's 330p flotation price. The shares, which had already risen in conditional trading on Friday and Monday, settled at 478p at 2pm.

The spike in the share price means that 227 shares bought from the government for £749.10, the allocation to each of the 690,000 retail investors, are now worth about £1,090 – a £340 increase.

More than 20m shares had changed hands before 2pm, but this was significantly less than the 100m traded in the first hour on Friday, when those who bought via a broker could start selling their shares.

Stockbroker Hargreaves Lansdown was so overwhelmed with demand on Friday that its website crashed and phone lines were jammed.

The Bristol-based brokerage said it was "very busy" again on Tuesday but its service was back to normal.

David Jones, chief market strategist at spread-betting firm IG Index, said about half of the shares traded on Tuesday were sold by retail investors.

Jones said many of the buyers were wealthy individuals who failed to buy any Royal Mail shares after the government decided to block applications from anyone who ordered more than £10,000 in shares. "The most active [buyers] are high net worth clients who missed out on the allocations they wanted," he said.

The further surge in the share price, which values Royal Mail at £4.8bn compared with the government's maximum £3.3bn valuation, has fuelled accusations that the government sold off the 500-year-old company too cheaply.

Adrian Bailey, the Labour chair of the business department select committee, said the share price surge "vindicated" concerns the committee raised when it questioned the business secretary, Vince Cable, last week.

"At the meeting last week it's fair to say that members of the committee had one view and the secretary of state had another," Bailey said. "The share price movements have vindicated the concerns of the committee members. Let's see where the price settles."

Bailey said the committee will also question Lazard, the investment bank that advised the government on how much to sell the shares.

Michael Fallon, the business minister in charge of the privatisation, and Danny Alexander, the chief secretary to the Treasury, joined Royal Mail's chief executive, Moya Greene, at the London Stock Exchange to officially mark the postal service's first day as a public company.

"This marks the exciting next phase in our company's long and proud history," she said. "With the support of our new shareholders, we are in a strong position to move forward, to compete effectively across our markets and to grow our business.

"Royal Mail will continue to be an essential part of the fabric of the UK, providing the universal postal service that is cherished by the 29m households and businesses across the country that we serve."

Meanwhile hundreds of Royal Mail workers met for a final mass meeting before the Communication Workers Union, which represents more than 100,000 postal workers, announces the results of a strike ballot on Wednesday.

Dave Ward, CWU deputy general secretary, said: "We may have lost the battle over privatisation, but we are here to fight the war for jobs, services and terms and conditions in Royal Mail and the wider postal industry. Privatisation makes the need for a legally binding deal on jobs more important than ever. CWU is here for the long term, regardless of who owns this company."

The CWU said it is "almost certain" that its 115,000 members will vote for industrial action.A nationwide strike, the first since 2009, could be held as soon as 23 October.

The 99% of Royal Mail's 150,000 workers who accepted £2,200 worth of free shares as part of the privatisation have made paper profits of more than £900, although they cannot sell the shares for three years.

webTitle: Boost for London as China agrees to loosen yuan investment rules

fields.standfirst: City gets edge over other financial centres with investors able to apply for licences to buy Chinese stocks and bonds directly
fields.body:
Beijing will give London-based institutions the right to invest directly into China using the yuan, George Osborne has announced, giving the City an edge over other financial centres fighting for business.

Investors will be able to apply for licences to buy Chinese stocks and bonds – rather than having to go via Hong Kong – with an initial quota of 80bn yuan (£8.2bn), under the extension of the Renminbi Qualified Financial Institutional Investor scheme.

Chinese banks will also be able to apply to open wholesale branches in Britain, rather than using tightly regulated subsidiaries – encouraging them to expand their activity in the UK.

"Today we agreed the next big step in making London – already the global centre for finance – a major global centre for trading and investing the Chinese currency too," the chancellor told reporters at a briefing in Beijing on Tuesday after talks with the Chinese vice-premier Ma Kai.

"More trade and more investment means more business and more jobs for Britain."

Osborne's five-day trade mission marks a thaw in bilateral relations after China called off high-level visits over David Cameron's meeting with the Dalai Lama last year.

The UK and China have also agreed to allow direct trading between sterling and the yuan, rather than via the dollar. The pound will become the fourth currency to trade directly with the yuan, following the US and Australian dollars and the yen, though it is unclear when trading will begin.

China is seeking to internationalise its currency, but is treading cautiously due to fears over volatility. The UK is already a global hub for trading other currencies.

Britain accounts for 62% of yuan trading outside China and Hong Kong. Daily trade in London has risen to around $5bn (£3.1bn) since it began last year.

Osborne later announced on Twitter that the ICBC bank would issue a yuan bond in London next month.

Chinese banks have been pushing hard for the right to open branches and several warned the Treasury last year that they were moving much of their business to Luxembourg because of the restrictions imposed by their subsidiary status.

The new arrangements will allow them to deal with companies and financial institutions, but not individual customers. Branch status allows them to draw on the capital of their main operations; the hope is that they will be able to invest more in the UK.

Creating new branches is cheaper and more efficient for the banks. Regulators are concerned that branches face looser controls; but should they need rescuing, their home governments must take responsibility, while Britain covers subsidiaries. Banks from the US and several European countries have branches in the UK.

The two countries also signed a memorandum of understanding on civil nuclear co-operation, paving the way for a Chinese state-owned nuclear power company to join EDF Energy in building a new plant at Hinkley Point.

"Chinese investment in our infrastructure is welcome," said Osborne.

"Like all investments they have to be done in an open and transparent way, but we have seen investment already in London's water supply and Heathrow airport and we have found China to be very straightforward partners in investment. Equally, there is a huge amount of British investment in China."

Other announcements by the chancellor include Chinese investment in Manchester's Airport City development and visa changes to encourage wealthy Chinese people to visit the UK.

Mark Henderson, chairman of the London Luxury Quarter, said the new procedures could give an enormous boost to the fortunes of British retailers. Chinese tourists spent £262m across Mayfair, Piccadilly and St James's in 2012, a 32% increase year-on-year. But at present Britain gets only 200,000 of the two million Chinese who visit Europe annually.

webTitle: Former Royal Bank of Scotland trader linked to currency market fixing

fields.standfirst: Financial Conduct Authority reportedly looking at instant messages sent by Richard Usher, now at JP Morgan
fields.body:
Electronic messages that Royal Bank of Scotland handed to the City regulator in connection with potential manipulation of the £3tn-a day currency market are reported to have been sent by the bailed-out bank's former trader Richard Usher.

The messages are said to be among those handed to the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) by the bank, which is 81% owned by the taxpayer.

Usher, who could not be reached for comment, is now the head of spot trading at JP Morgan in London. He has been listed as a member of a Bank of England committee that polices a voluntary code of group practice for the markets.

The regulatory review by the FCA, which has not yet escalated its inquiries into a formal investigation, implies no wrongdoing by Usher, according to the Bloomberg news agency, which revealed his identity.

The analysis of the electronic messages is the latest move by regulators to test the integrity of benchmarks used to price financial products in the light of the Libor-rigging scandal as well as manipulation of gas prices. The investigation was triggered by reports in the Guardian last year.

The FCA said in June it was looking at foreign exchange markets after Bloomberg reported that traders at some banks were sharing information about their positions through instant messages. These were said to be a way to manipulate an index compiled by WM/Reuters and based on prices of currencies for a 60-second period.

The Swiss regulator has since begun an investigation, and US authorities are said be looking at the situation.

Last week RBS refused to comment on a report that it had handed the FCA instant messages sent to and from a currency trader who no longer works for the bank and who left before any questions were asked. JP Morgan, RBS and the FCA declined to comment on the latest reports.

The FCA register says Usher has worked at JP Morgan since 2010 but it does not show any history of him working at RBS, where he most probably did not hold a role that required him to be on the register.

The Wall Street Journal said the instant messages were allegedly sent to a group of traders known as the bandits' club or the cartel.

webTitle: In praise of empiricism: a Nobel prize for everyday economics | Heidi Moore

fields.standfirst: Fama, Shiller and Hansen are worthy winners for focusing on the messy reality of market behaviour, rather than abstract theories
fields.body:
This summer, I took a look at my retirement account. It was pathetic.

Scattered across a random group of mutual funds – growth, value, tech, emerging markets, what have you – my retirement dollars were all making skimpy profits, even though the market was good. The stockpickers running those funds had one job – to do better than the S&P 500 – and they were clearly failing.

I moved my entire retirement nest egg into an index fund, which essentially just imitates the S&P 500 with no stockpicking or other funny stuff. The result: my little nest egg ballooned by thousands of dollars in just a few months.

I forgot to thank one man for my move: Eugene Fama. The man who won the Nobel memorial award in economics Monday discovered years ago that stockpicking was a fool's game; you can't really beat the market. An entire industry of index funds exists because of Fama's research.

His two co-winners are also men who care what happens in the real world. Economics has a reputation as wonky, nerdy discipline that loves theories that are pure and distant from humanity, like cottony clouds, and hates to get its hands dirty with real-world concerns. This year's Nobel prize in economics is finally, a victory for the study of human nature.

The three winners this year – Eugene Fama, Robert Shiller and Peter Lars Hansen – study stock and bond markets and the abnormal psychology of bubbles, and why we fail to pick stocks. They are interested in numbers, yes, but mostly, they are interested in how real people behave under financial stress. Fama said Monday:

Finance drew me in because it's so fundamental to human activity. It follows precise mathematical relations but there's an element of imprecision that reflects human nature.

One winner, Robert Shiller, created an influential housing index. He is known for spotting bubbles early. The other winner, Lars Peter Hansen, found new ways of thinking about stocks and risk. And Fama showed that investors can't really beat the market in the short term; when you invest in an S&P 500 index fund, you're making use of his work, just as I did. A colleague at the University of Chicago said during the ceremony that Fama had had "a phenomenal impact on the practical world and people's lives."

Fama, Hansen and Shiller have often disagreed about the specifics of how the real world works. Fama has said he doesn't believe in bubbles; Shiller, who wrote the book Irrational Exuberance, spots them. But what unites them is that these are three men who aren't looking for the perfect world. They're happy to figure out a world in which orderly spreadsheets of numbers are overwhelmed by the venal, panicky, chaotic tendencies of humanity in a crisis.

This is the kind of economics we need more of: the kind that speaks to us. With the financial crisis and recession, economics are part of our daily lives. The unemployment rate, housing sales, mortgage lending rates … we all live with these numbers weekly, in our communities and in our wallets. Those numbers are part of the study of economics. They also describe the world we live in.
A lot of economics, however, depends on unreliable numbers. It's not about the cold, hard truth.
